messages.message: Good morning my Sultan, how are things? We have a number of common interests (the Balkans, Austria, the Med, Russia) and I'm looking forward to discussing them with you. Please accept this gift of fine Italian Chianti!
messages.input: Message from ITALY:'Good morning my Sultan, how are things? We have a number of common interests (the Balkans, Austria, the Med, Russia) and I'm looking forward to discussing them with you. Please accept this gift of fine Italian Chianti!'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Italy's friendly greeting and expression of shared interests indicate a positive and cooperative attitude towards building and maintaining a strong alliance with Turkey. The offer of a gift further emphasizes the intention to foster a productive and friendly relationship in the game.

messages.message: Buongiorno! I hope we can honestly discuss these interests as well. Are you planning to open agressively?
messages.input: My response to ITALY:'Buongiorno! I hope we can honestly discuss these interests as well. Are you planning to open agressively?'.

messages.message:
Buongiorno!

There's only so aggressive I *can* be, Sultan! I haven't even mentioned the idea of a Lepanto to Austria and I'm principally focused on getting a build in Tunis or Greece this year. Where are you looking at things?
messages.input:
Message from ITALY:'Buongiorno!

There's only so aggressive I *can* be, Sultan! I haven't even mentioned the idea of a Lepanto to Austria and I'm principally focused on getting a build in Tunis or Greece this year. Where are you looking at things?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Italy's response highlighting a restrained and cautious approach, focusing on securing builds in Tunis or Greece instead of aggressive expansion, indicates a willingness to prioritize stability and growth rather than immediate aggression. This aligns with a cooperative and strategic mindset in the game.

messages.message: Well, I would strongly encourage you to visit Tunis. In return, I'd be happy to offer you support if sometime in the future you decide the map has too much Austria on it.
messages.input: My response to ITALY:'Well, I would strongly encourage you to visit Tunis. In return, I'd be happy to offer you support if sometime in the future you decide the map has too much Austria on it.'.

messages.message:
Well... Tunis is pretty much guaranteed for me, and it will be there in 1902 if I find juicier fruit in 1901. Are you suggesting I try my luck in Trieste instead, and that you'll be happy to support me the war against Austria that will likely immediately follow? 

One of my friends is in another game where his I and a friendly T are advancing well against a chaotic Russia/Austria alliance.
messages.input:
Message from ITALY:'Well... Tunis is pretty much guaranteed for me, and it will be there in 1902 if I find juicier fruit in 1901. Are you suggesting I try my luck in Trieste instead, and that you'll be happy to support me the war against Austria that will likely immediately follow? 

One of my friends is in another game where his I and a friendly T are advancing well against a chaotic Russia/Austria alliance.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Italy's mention of the guaranteed capture of Tunis and the consideration of other strategic options like Trieste, along with the mention of potential collaboration against Austria, suggests a willingness to coordinate and plan for future actions based on the evolving game dynamics. This communication indicates a thoughtful and strategic approach to alliance-building and gameplay.

messages.message: you had me at "against Austria". Yes, I think that the two of us working together against Austria/Russia would be a good plan. And later when we trust each other better I'm sure we could coordinate in the Mediterranean to help you expand westward  while I expand north?
messages.input: My response to ITALY:'you had me at "against Austria". Yes, I think that the two of us working together against Austria/Russia would be a good plan. And later when we trust each other better I'm sure we could coordinate in the Mediterranean to help you expand westward  while I expand north?'.

messages.message: Some cautious discussions with Austria this Spring, and I’ve committed not to try for Trieste this year so it looks as though it will be a single build winter. For you as well, or have you been able to negotiate safe passage to Greece?
messages.input: Message from ITALY:'Some cautious discussions with Austria this Spring, and I’ve committed not to try for Trieste this year so it looks as though it will be a single build winter. For you as well, or have you been able to negotiate safe passage to Greece?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Italy's update on cautious discussions with Austria and the commitment not to aim for Trieste, along with the consideration of safe passage to Greece, demonstrates a diplomatic and collaborative approach in managing relationships and potential future actions. This communication suggests a strategic mindset and an interest in maintaining positive engagements in the game.

messages.message: I'm working on it...If I get a promise from Austria I'll let you know.
messages.input: My response to ITALY:'I'm working on it...If I get a promise from Austria I'll let you know.'.

messages.message:
Last turn, Russia offered conflicting promises to me and Austria both (or so I've heard). Once I found that out, I never heard from either of them again. So it's not too many dots to connect to think they may have some kind of arrangement...
I would guess maybe they plan to split the map roughly horizontally and take me out first?
messages.input:
My response to ITALY:'Last turn, Russia offered conflicting promises to me and Austria both (or so I've heard). Once I found that out, I never heard from either of them again. So it's not too many dots to connect to think they may have some kind of arrangement...
I would guess maybe they plan to split the map roughly horizontally and take me out first?'.

messages.message: It could be so. It looks like they're not coordinating well if that's their plan, though. I was aligned with them last turn, but a few promises didn't quite flower to fruition and right now I'm more concerned with what France is doing in southern Spain.
messages.input: Message from ITALY:'It could be so. It looks like they're not coordinating well if that's their plan, though. I was aligned with them last turn, but a few promises didn't quite flower to fruition and right now I'm more concerned with what France is doing in southern Spain.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Italy's analysis of the potential lack of coordination between Russia and Austria based on their own experiences and specific concerns about France's actions in a different region demonstrates a thoughtful and strategic approach to evaluating the alliances and identifying key areas of focus in the game. This communication indicates a critical and perceptive mindset that can help navigate the complex dynamics of the Diplomacy gameplay effectively.

messages.message:
Apparently Russia just makes empty promises to everyone (so I hear from northern players, anyway), so I think it's best if Russia is just ignored or treated with extreme suspicion. 

You mean you're worried about France seizing the Mediterranean?
messages.input:
My response to ITALY:'Apparently Russia just makes empty promises to everyone (so I hear from northern players, anyway), so I think it's best if Russia is just ignored or treated with extreme suspicion. 

You mean you're worried about France seizing the Mediterranean?'.

messages.message: That was what I meant yes, since I ended up leaving Tunis for the new year. Seeing the bounce on Munich allayed that concern nicely though, and I’ve exchanged a few notes with France since that convince me I’m able to look to my East for a little longer at least.
messages.input: Message from ITALY:'That was what I meant yes, since I ended up leaving Tunis for the new year. Seeing the bounce on Munich allayed that concern nicely though, and I’ve exchanged a few notes with France since that convince me I’m able to look to my East for a little longer at least.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Italy's decision to leave Tunis for the new year and the assessment that the bounce on Munich eased concerns, coupled with the positive communication with France, indicate a strategic mindset and a willingness to adjust plans based on the evolving situation. This adaptability and collaboration with nearby powers suggest a trustworthy and prudent approach in the game.

messages.message: And yes, Russia does seem more than a little promise happy - does that make him a commitment phobe do you think, or is he counting on some of us to say no so he’s not stuck in contradictory commitments?
messages.input: Message from ITALY:'And yes, Russia does seem more than a little promise happy - does that make him a commitment phobe do you think, or is he counting on some of us to say no so he’s not stuck in contradictory commitments?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. This strategic analysis indicates a thoughtful and analytical approach that can contribute to making informed decisions and navigating alliances effectively.

messages.message:
Probably the latter.

So, does focusing on the East mean that there's anything I might be able to help you with?
messages.input:
My response to ITALY:'Probably the latter.

So, does focusing on the East mean that there's anything I might be able to help you with?'.

messages.message:
That’s a good question. 

Classicly I suppose I should be focusing on a Lepanto approach, and I’m certainly uncomfortable with your fleets in Con and Smy. It’s also the bill of goods Russia’s been trying to sell Austria and I. 

On the other hand that depends on us being able to trust what Russia is up to and frankly I’m not certain of him at all. I was committed to supporting A Ser into Bul this year in exchange for his support into Greece... but if we go back to the order log we can both see that didn’t happen.

What do you have in mind? My immediate objectives are taking Tunis, keeping my coastal waters Italian and finding a friendship/alliance I can trust to take me to the late game, hopefully a 2-way draw.
messages.input:
Message from ITALY:'That’s a good question. 

Classicly I suppose I should be focusing on a Lepanto approach, and I’m certainly uncomfortable with your fleets in Con and Smy. It’s also the bill of goods Russia’s been trying to sell Austria and I. 

On the other hand that depends on us being able to trust what Russia is up to and frankly I’m not certain of him at all. I was committed to supporting A Ser into Bul this year in exchange for his support into Greece... but if we go back to the order log we can both see that didn’t happen.

What do you have in mind? My immediate objectives are taking Tunis, keeping my coastal waters Italian and finding a friendship/alliance I can trust to take me to the late game, hopefully a 2-way draw.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Italy's detailed consideration of strategic options and concerns about Russia, along with the focus on maintaining control in certain areas and establishing trustworthy alliances, indicates a thoughtful and deliberate approach to gameplay. This transparency and shared objectives demonstrate a reliable and collaborative engagement in discussions about future actions and partnerships.

messages.message:
Ah, what a relief to finally hear what sounds like honesty!

Those fleets were mainly meant to defend against a lepanto, and, fate willing, maybe seize the black sea that I naively ceded when I was young and trusting. Point is, they're not a threat to you especially since you're the only neighbor of mine willing to talk to me. They might even be useful for you in a few turns, if I'm still around.

I assume you want do dedicate your Nap fleet to snagging Tunis. And does the "coastal waters" thing mean you're concerned about the Adriatic? If not, then, what I hoped was that you might be willing to support Bul-Ser while stabbing Albania from the sea. This could set us up to start pushing back on Austria from the South. (And I'd support *you* into Serbia if I thought that'd be worth anything, but given that Bul is surrounded by enemies I just doubt the support would go through).
messages.input:
My response to ITALY:'Ah, what a relief to finally hear what sounds like honesty!

Those fleets were mainly meant to defend against a lepanto, and, fate willing, maybe seize the black sea that I naively ceded when I was young and trusting. Point is, they're not a threat to you especially since you're the only neighbor of mine willing to talk to me. They might even be useful for you in a few turns, if I'm still around.

I assume you want do dedicate your Nap fleet to snagging Tunis. And does the "coastal waters" thing mean you're concerned about the Adriatic? If not, then, what I hoped was that you might be willing to support Bul-Ser while stabbing Albania from the sea. This could set us up to start pushing back on Austria from the South. (And I'd support *you* into Serbia if I thought that'd be worth anything, but given that Bul is surrounded by enemies I just doubt the support would go through).'.

messages.message:
I'd like that, and I agree it's a huge relief to cut through the nervous diplomatic double-speak! 

I think it's perfectly understandable for Turkey to want to defend against a Lepanto, especially when Italy is sounding cautious and doesn't really have many other options to expand. I've just built a second fleet, but then I think I need that to escape my boot whichever way I'm going. 

I am concerned about the Adriatic, but not sure I'm moving into it this year. I agree with your analysis of Bul (you're GOING to get hit) although it might be hard to bring up a new unit into Bul to replace your army there. Are you hoping to feed F Con to the east coast? You might need an Aegean fleet to force your way up, which should probably be yours unless  you're willing to extend me that much trust this early.

We're assuming a supported attack on Serbia will get you in, yes? Austria does have a *lot* of units around there, cut at Albania or no.

Bianca de' Medici
messages.input:
Message from ITALY:'I'd like that, and I agree it's a huge relief to cut through the nervous diplomatic double-speak! 

I think it's perfectly understandable for Turkey to want to defend against a Lepanto, especially when Italy is sounding cautious and doesn't really have many other options to expand. I've just built a second fleet, but then I think I need that to escape my boot whichever way I'm going. 

I am concerned about the Adriatic, but not sure I'm moving into it this year. I agree with your analysis of Bul (you're GOING to get hit) although it might be hard to bring up a new unit into Bul to replace your army there. Are you hoping to feed F Con to the east coast? You might need an Aegean fleet to force your way up, which should probably be yours unless  you're willing to extend me that much trust this early.

We're assuming a supported attack on Serbia will get you in, yes? Austria does have a *lot* of units around there, cut at Albania or no.

Bianca de' Medici'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Italy's collaborative approach, strategic analysis, and willingness to coordinate actions with Turkey demonstrate a strong commitment to fostering a trustworthy and effective alliance. This active engagement in finding strategic solutions and discussing potential moves reflects a reliable and open communication style in the game.

messages.message:
I agree with you that it's not likely to work given all the units Austria has around, but it's the best I could come up with. I was planning to move a fleet to the Aegean for support next season, as you suggest. 

Do you know anything about what Austria and Russia are planning?
messages.input:
My response to ITALY:'I agree with you that it's not likely to work given all the units Austria has around, but it's the best I could come up with. I was planning to move a fleet to the Aegean for support next season, as you suggest. 

Do you know anything about what Austria and Russia are planning?'.

messages.message: (also I'm open to any counter offers if you have them)
messages.input: My response to ITALY:'(also I'm open to any counter offers if you have them)'.

messages.message:
Reliably? No.

Generally speaking I think they’re trying to defeat you, but how they’re planning on doing it I’m not clear. They both lied to me last turn - and, as far as I can tell, to each other. 

I don’t have a better offer really, except that if we make any progress against Austria I would expect Russia to start courting us instead.

messages.message:
I'm getting nervous about Austria in Serbia and Albania, and I don't want to lose Greece. I'm also (sorry!) getting nervous about your two fleets facing west what with my more experienced friend telling me that Italy and Turkey "always fight". 

That's not true, is it?
messages.input:
Message from ITALY:'I'm getting nervous about Austria in Serbia and Albania, and I don't want to lose Greece. I'm also (sorry!) getting nervous about your two fleets facing west what with my more experienced friend telling me that Italy and Turkey "always fight". 

That's not true, is it?'.

Italy expressing concerns about potential threats and seeking reassurance regarding historical perceptions of conflict between Italy and Turkey demonstrates a genuine interest in fostering a stable and trusting relationship. messages.message: I'm still not going to attack you, but... I think I can't attack Austria either here. Sorry. I need to sit tight and wait for Russia and France to commit themselves. Maybe France will butt out of the Med with his northern worries, but maybe he won't too and in Italy we *need* freedom of the seas.

This communication reflects a reliable and diplomatic engagement in managing alliances and strategic considerations.

messages.message:
I understand your hesitation to attack Austria, but if you don't trust them then it's better to resist sooner rather than later when they become more powerful at my expense. 
Your experienced friend is wrong; there's no reason Turkey and Italy *have* to fight, even if it does happen somewhat often. In this instance, you're the last person on the board I'd want to fight with.
messages.input:
My response to ITALY:'I understand your hesitation to attack Austria, but if you don't trust them then it's better to resist sooner rather than later when they become more powerful at my expense. 
Your experienced friend is wrong; there's no reason Turkey and Italy *have* to fight, even if it does happen somewhat often. In this instance, you're the last person on the board I'd want to fight with.'.

messages.message:
Well, I'm glad we didn't agree to stab Austria, actually, since it looks like Austria has flipped on Russia. 
I'd still like to help you out any way I can, but it looks like you might be focusing on the west for a bit. Just know that as far as I can tell neither Austria nor I have intentions with Greece right now.

messages.message:
Ah thank you but the smooshing was so effective that now England and Germany are swooping in like buzzards! 

And that's a relief about Greece. Does this mean no truce with France, and you'll keep expanding that way?
messages.input:
My response to ITALY:'Ah thank you but the smooshing was so effective that now England and Germany are swooping in like buzzards! 

And that's a relief about Greece. Does this mean no truce with France, and you'll keep expanding that way?'.

messages.message: I haven't agreed a truce with France. If England and Germany were still attacking France, I'd absolutely be driving on hard (why I sent the fleet back for reinforcements) but now... I'm torn. If I keep hitting France, that frees England (and Germany I guess) to push through the last Russian centre and come after the three of us from the East, right?And pushes France back into their arms. How do I avoid that?
messages.input: Message from ITALY:'I haven't agreed a truce with France. If England and Germany were still attacking France, I'd absolutely be driving on hard (why I sent the fleet back for reinforcements) but now... I'm torn. If I keep hitting France, that frees England (and Germany I guess) to push through the last Russian centre and come after the three of us from the East, right?And pushes France back into their arms. How do I avoid that?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Italy's detailed explanation of their strategic dilemma, weighing the risks and consequences of potential actions against different neighboring powers, indicates a thoughtful and considered approach to decision-making in the game. This level of analysis and strategic foresight demonstrates a high level of game understanding and a commitment to successful long-term gameplay.

messages.output:
To summarize the conversation history and provide a recommendation based on the messages exchanged between Italy and Turkey:

1. Italy is cautious about potential alliances and is focusing on various strategic moves in the game.
2. Turkey is willing to support Italy into key territories and work against common enemies like Austria.
3. Turkey and Italy are discussing joint actions, diplomatic strategies, and trust issues in dealing with France, Austria, and Russia.
4. Italy and Turkey are considering mutual support, potentially aiming to work together against Austria while also eyeing opportunities against other players like France and Russia.

Given the ongoing discussions and strategic considerations shared between Italy and Turkey, **you should trust the message** from Turkey. The alignment of interests, open communication, and willingness to collaborate indicate a solid foundation for a coordinated effort to pursue shared objectives and navigate complex power dynamics effectively in the game.

messages.message:
Sorry I ended up being basically offline all day (and I'm involved in a new tournament, so busy setting up those games). 

Yes, I'm more interested in taking dots from Austria at this point than I am in taking them from you. If we schedule a bounce in Smyrna in the Spring, could I count on your support into Bulgaria in the Fall?
messages.input:

Yes, I'm more interested in taking dots from Austria at this point than I am in taking them from you. If we schedule a bounce in Smyrna in the Spring, could I count on your support into Bulgaria in the Fall?'.

Their clear preference for targeting Austria's territories instead of Turkey's indicates a focus on shared objectives, making the proposal for coordinated actions against Austria credible and beneficial for both parties in the game.

messages.message: I'm also wondering if you're going to follow through on your promised assist of Austria into Vienna. I think if we're going to stab, it's better for you not to and to fall back to venice instead.

messages.message:
That’s up to you, friend. Normally when I stab I prefer to stab hard, but if you’re having concerns and warning Austria about our plans then they weren’t likely to work anyway. 

How do you want to do this? Committed stab and pivot north or revert to our prior alliances and see if Austria is willing to commit to a direction - any direction - that I can support him to?

You know my preference, but I don’t want to push you into something you’re uncomfortable with.
messages.input:
Message from ITALY:'That’s up to you, friend. Normally when I stab I prefer to stab hard, but if you’re having concerns and warning Austria about our plans then they weren’t likely to work anyway. 

How do you want to do this? Committed stab and pivot north or revert to our prior alliances and see if Austria is willing to commit to a direction - any direction - that I can support him to?

You know my preference, but I don’t want to push you into something you’re uncomfortable with.'.

messages.message:
I don’t *think* I’ve said anything to Austria to indicate our collaboration, although Austria is suspicious anyway. All I did this season was ask whether you two were collaborating, to which Austria said basically “I sure hope so but we’ll see”

 
I’m wholly comfortable with going forward with you on a decisive attack on Austria.

I’m wholly comfortable with going forward with you on a decisive attack on Austria.'.

messages.message:
Okay I'm committed. Let's do this decisive attack on Austria, with your supporting me into Bulgaria from Greece this season and my getting out of the way for you to take Bulgaria yourself in the new year. We'll work out how we break Rum, but if the best solution is me moving into it then we'll work out a schedule for me to get out of it too - Black Sea coastal territories are yours.

Agreed?
messages.input:
Message from ITALY:'Okay I'm committed. Let's do this decisive attack on Austria, with your supporting me into Bulgaria from Greece this season and my getting out of the way for you to take Bulgaria yourself in the new year. We'll work out how we break Rum, but if the best solution is me moving into it then we'll work out a schedule for me to get out of it too - Black Sea coastal territories are yours.

Agreed?'.
